review.snippet: After seeing Everybody's Fine, Paul McCartney offered to write a song that plays over the closing credits. That may be because the whole movie is like a celluloid McCartney tune: warm and playful and sweetly earnest, but lightly funny, too, and crafted with consummate skill.
Here, the actor (Di Niro) dials it down and wins us over.
The movie works because so much of what's on screen will resonate with viewers.
At one point, Frank contemplates a wheeled suitcase and infuses in that one moment the sweetness and vulnerability of E.T. See Everybody's Fine, but one piece of advice: Phone home first.

"Relief" is the word for it. It's a relief to see Robert De Niro giving an honest, effective starring performance in a project that does not stink and that, in fact, rises to a respectable level of filmmaking proficiency. How long has it been?
De Niro's minimalist performance has maximum emotional impact and succeeds in unifying the episodic film.
Now comes this American version, which turns out to be the exception, an American remake that's better than the European original.
This is sentimental but dramatically solid, its placid themes fortified by De Niro.
All that could redeem this thoroughly foreseeable unfolding would be colorful characters and good acting. Everybody's Fine comes close, but not close enough.
What's finest about Everybody's Fine is to watch a good fella groping hopefully toward old age.

Though a bit too artful to merit the pejorative "tearjerker" label, the film is rigorously streamlined to deliver a good emotional uppercut by the end, and purely on the strength of its craft, it connects.
This is the kind of work a great actor does when he's not preoccupied with giving a great performance. Its very casualness is its big selling point.
If nothing else (and there ain't much else), Everybody's Fine does prove one thing: Even an actor with the gifts of Robert De Niro can't make bland interesting.
De Niro, trying his ordinary-guy best not to be mannered, gives one of his most mannered performances.
Once it’s clear the movie won’t be deviating at all from its formula, Frank’s journey gets tedious.
Follows a dispiritingly predictable arc.
It’s offensive, really, this blatant pandering to emotions.
Robert De Niro's only good at playing a dad in movies starring Ben Stiller? It's all so much raging bull.
It's a syrupy, downbeat film.
No trite, tear-jerking cliché goes undrooled in the script by director Kirk Jones.
Everybody’s Fine – a movie about the lies grown children tell their parents – is, ironically, one of the most disingenuous movies to come out of Hollywood in a while.
Calculatedly soppy, seasonally phony Americanized remake of Giuseppe Tornatore's 1990 "Stanno Tutti Bene."
A cloyingly sentimental story that rings false in every moment.
Even supremely talented actors like Melissa Leo (as a confidently sexy trucker) and Brendan Sexton III (as a train-station beggar) are stifled by all the pseudo-redemptive mush.
The queasiness produced by this sentimental weepie builds into a wave of nausea during its interminable finale.
